elements.content: A (3,12)-connected 3D metal-organic framework has been synthesized based on octanuclear zinc clusters as 12-connected nodes and flexible carboxylate ligands as 3-connected nodes, and it represents the highest connected binodal network topology presently known for metal-organic frameworks.
elements.clean_text: A (3,12)-connected 3D metal-organic framework has been synthesized based on octanuclear zinc clusters as 12-connected nodes and flexible carboxylate ligands as 3-connected nodes, and it represents the highest connected binodal network topology presently known for metal-organic frameworks.

elements.content: A (3,12)-connected 3D metal-organic framework has been synthesized based on octanuclear zinc clusters as 12-connected nodes and flexible carboxylate ligands as 3-connected nodes, and it represents the highest connected binodal network topology presently known for metal-organic frameworks.
elements.clean_text: A (3,12)-connected 3D metal-organic framework has been synthesized based on octanuclear zinc clusters as 12-connected nodes and flexible carboxylate ligands as 3-connected nodes, and it represents the highest connected binodal network topology presently known for metal-organic frameworks.

elements.content: Current interest in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is rapidly expanding for their intriguing architectures and potential applications, although true crystal engineering of MOFs (i.e., prediction of the solid-state structure precisely) still remains a long-term challenge for crystal engineers. The topological analysis of multitudinous networks has been a topical research area, which is not only an important tool for simplifying complicated compounds but also plays an instructive role in the rational design of some functional materials with desired properties. To date, the topologies of many MOFs generally can be analyzed and categorized with some natural prototypes in metallic or binary inorganic solids, and they have been discussed in several notable reviews following a seminal compilation by Wells decades ago. A variety of uninodal network topologies have been realized. The majorities are based on 3-, 4-, and 6-connected topologies. Examples of 7-, 8- and 12-connected metal-organic coordination frameworks are extremely rare because of the limited coordination numbers of metal centers and the steric hindrance issues of most commonly used organic ligands. On the other hand, some metal-organic frameworks with mixed-connected topologies have been reported, for example: Pt3O4, boracite, twisted boracite, PtS, rutile, pyrite, and anatase. However, there is an unfavorable lack of investigation on binodal high-connected structures, such as (3,8), (4,8), (3,9), and (3,10)-connected frameworks. The (3,12)-connected framework, compared with the above-mentioned nets, is more difficult to achieve because it contains higher-connected nodes. Up to now, the (3,12)-connected 3D framework via using covalent linkage has not been observed in MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Current interest in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is rapidly expanding for their intriguing architectures and potential applications, although true crystal engineering of MOFs (i.e., prediction of the solid-state structure precisely) still remains a long-term challenge for crystal engineers. The topological analysis of multitudinous networks has been a topical research area, which is not only an important tool for simplifying complicated compounds but also plays an instructive role in the rational design of some functional materials with desired properties. To date, the topologies of many MOFs generally can be analyzed and categorized with some natural prototypes in metallic or binary inorganic solids, and they have been discussed in several notable reviews following a seminal compilation by Wells decades ago. A variety of uninodal network topologies have been realized. The majorities are based on 3-, 4-, and 6-connected topologies. Examples of 7-, 8- and 12-connected metal-organic coordination frameworks are extremely rare because of the limited coordination numbers of metal centers and the steric hindrance issues of most commonly used organic ligands. On the other hand, some metal-organic frameworks with mixed-connected topologies have been reported, for example: Pt3O4, boracite, twisted boracite, PtS, rutile, pyrite, and anatase. However, there is an unfavorable lack of investigation on binodal high-connected structures, such as (3,8), (4,8), (3,9), and (3,10)-connected frameworks. The (3,12)-connected framework, compared with the above-mentioned nets, is more difficult to achieve because it contains higher-connected nodes. Up to now, the (3,12)-connected 3D framework via using covalent linkage has not been observed in MOFs.

elements.content: Recently, the utilization of metal clusters as nodes in place of single-metal ions has provided a promising pathway toward the generation of highly connected MOFs. In our recent work, we have synthesized a novel binodal high-connected compound, [Zn2.5L(bdc)2.5] · H2O (L = 1-((4′-((pyridin-3-yloxy)methyl)biphenyl-4-yl)methyl)pyridinium-3-olate), which is the first (6,8)-connected self-penetrating MOF based on two distinct zinc clusters: dinuclear and trinuclear zinc clusters. If we can synthesize the bigger multinuclear zinc clusters, even if nanosized units, the higher-connected frameworks will be obtained. Taking these into account, we chose the flexible dicarboxylate ligand 4,4′-oxybis(benzoate) (H2oba) and nitrogenous flexible ligand 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole) (bbi) as linkers based on the following considerations: (i) The synthesis of metal clusters usually is to control the hydrolysis of metal salts with the aid of carboxylate ligands, and the carboxylate group may induce core aggregation, chelate metal ions, and lock their position into metal−oxygen clusters. (ii) The bbi ligand is selected for constructing MOFs because it is a long flexible ligand with small steric hindrance, which can link discrete clusters into an extended network via its bridging ability and should be feasible to form high-connected 3D networks.
elements.clean_text: Recently, the utilization of metal clusters as nodes in place of single-metal ions has provided a promising pathway toward the generation of highly connected MOFs. In our recent work, we have synthesized a novel binodal high-connected compound, [Zn2.5L(bdc)2.5] ⋅ H2O (L = 1-((4'-((pyridin-3-yloxy)methyl)biphenyl-4-yl)methyl)pyridinium-3-olate), which is the first (6,8)-connected self-penetrating MOF based on two distinct zinc clusters: dinuclear and trinuclear zinc clusters. If we can synthesize the bigger multinuclear zinc clusters, even if nanosized units, the higher-connected frameworks will be obtained. Taking these into account, we chose the flexible dicarboxylate ligand 4,4'-oxybis(benzoate) (H2oba) and nitrogenous flexible ligand 1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole) (bbi) as linkers based on the following considerations: (i) The synthesis of metal clusters usually is to control the hydrolysis of metal salts with the aid of carboxylate ligands, and the carboxylate group may induce core aggregation, chelate metal ions, and lock their position into metal-oxygen clusters. (ii) The bbi ligand is selected for constructing MOFs because it is a long flexible ligand with small steric hindrance, which can link discrete clusters into an extended network via its bridging ability and should be feasible to form high-connected 3D networks.

elements.content: As accurate prediction of the final structures is impossible, we have tried different synthetic conditions (such as reaction temperature, pH value, solvent, and molar ratio of the raw materials) to synthesize multinuclear zinc clusters units to construct high-connected frameworks. Fortunately, compound [Zn8(μ3-OH)4(oba)6(bbi)(H2O)2] (1) is isolated by hydrothermal methods. The product is very stable in air and the framework begins to decompose when heated to as high as 321 °C (see Figure S1 in the ). To the best of our knowledge, it represents the first example of (3,12)-connected 3D framework via using covalent linkage based on nanosized octanuclear zinc clusters. Of particular mention is that compound 1 exhibits interesting photoelectronic properties.
elements.clean_text: As accurate prediction of the final structures is impossible, we have tried different synthetic conditions (such as reaction temperature, pH value, solvent, and molar ratio of the raw materials) to synthesize multinuclear zinc clusters units to construct high-connected frameworks. Fortunately, compound [Zn8(μ3-OH)4(oba)6(bbi)(H2O)2] (1) is isolated by hydrothermal methods. The product is very stable in air and the framework begins to decompose when heated to as high as 321 °C (see Figure S1 in the ). To the best of our knowledge, it represents the first example of (3,12)-connected 3D framework via using covalent linkage based on nanosized octanuclear zinc clusters. Of particular mention is that compound 1 exhibits interesting photoelectronic properties.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis shows that the structure of 1 is made up of four kinds of crystallographical unique Zn cations, three kinds of oba anions, one kind of bbi ligand, μ3-OH group and water molecule (see Figure S2 in the ). Four kinds of Zn cations exhibit three different coordination geometries. Zn1 atom is coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from different oba ligands, two μ3-OH groups and one water molecule to complete a distorted octahedral environment. Zn2 and Zn3 are four-coordinated and exhibit distorted tetrahedral geometries, which are surrounded by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from different oba ligands and one μ3-OH for Zn2, and one μ3-OH, two carboxylate oxygen atoms from different oba ligands and one nitrogen atom from a bbi ligand for Zn3, respectively. Whereas Zn4 is five-coordinated by two different μ3-OH and three carboxylate oxygen atoms from different oba ligands and exhibits a square pyramidal geometry. Each Zn1 octahedron links a Zn4 square pyramid by sharing one edge and two tetrahedra (Zn2 and Zn3) by sharing corners (μ3-OH) to generate a {Zn4} subunit, and two symmetry-related {Zn4} subunits assemble to an octanuclear cluster by sharing corners (μ3-OH) (panels a and b in Figure ). Thus, this unique octanuclear zinc cluster includes all the common coordination numbers of the Zn cation. This special phenomenon is similar to the recent reported compound [Zn2.5(BPTC)(L4)(OH)(H2O)] which shows penta-core zinc clusters. The presence of special coordination modes of ZnII ions may be due to various coordination modes of multicarboxylate ligand and the smaller steric hindrance of imidazole group. The nanosized octanuclear zinc cluster has the dimensions of approximately 10 × 11 × 4 Å3 (measured between opposite atoms along the three directions) with C 2 symmetry. In a previously reported for MOFs, two similar octanuclear zinc clusters [Zn8(SiO4)(CO2)12] and [Zn8(μ2-OH)4(CO2)12] have been found, in which all the Zn atoms are 4-coordinated. Moreover, it is interesting that three types of oba anions (oba1, oba2, and oba3) show different coordination modes (see Figure S3 in the ). As such, each octanuclear zinc cluster is surrounded by sixteen organic ligands (four oba1, four oba2, six oba3, and two bbi ligands) (Figure c). Each oba3 as a 3-connected node is connected to three octanuclear zinc clusters. Each pair of oba1 and oba2 links two octanuclear zinc clusters simultaneously as a linker. So each octanuclear zinc cluster as 12-connected node is further linked to six octanuclear zinc clusters and six 3-connected nodes (see Figure S4 in the ). The overall structure of 1 is a 3D (3,12)-connected framework. The Schläfli symbol for 1 is (32·4)2(38·422·516·618·72) (Figure ).

Zn1 atom is coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from different oba ligands, two μ3-OH groups and one water molecule to complete a distorted octahedral environment. Zn2 and Zn3 are four-coordinated and exhibit distorted tetrahedral geometries, which are surrounded by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from different oba ligands and one μ3-OH for Zn2, and one μ3-OH, two carboxylate oxygen atoms from different oba ligands and one nitrogen atom from a bbi ligand for Zn3, respectively. Whereas Zn4 is five-coordinated by two different μ3-OH and three carboxylate oxygen atoms from different oba ligands and exhibits a square pyramidal geometry. Each Zn1 octahedron links a Zn4 square pyramid by sharing one edge and two tetrahedra (Zn2 and Zn3) by sharing corners (μ3-OH) to generate a {Zn4} subunit, and two symmetry-related {Zn4} subunits assemble to an octanuclear cluster by sharing corners (μ3-OH) (panels a and b in Figure ). elements.content: (a) Schematic representation of the octanuclear zinc cluster as a 12-connected node. (b) Schematic representation of the (3,12)-connected 3D framework (purple and green balls represent 3-connected nodes and 12-connected nodes, respectively).

elements.content: Offering further insight into the nature of this intricate architecture, pairs of oba1 and oba2 bridges link octanuclear zinc clusters to form a (4,4) 2-D sheet, and octanuclear zinc clusters are bridged by oba3 ligands to show a (3,6)-connected sheet. Two kinds of sheets extent to a (3,10)-connected layer by sharing octanuclear zinc clusters along the bc plane (see Figure S5 in the ). Furthermore, bbi ligands connect these (3,10)-connected layers along the a axis to form the ultimate (3,12)-connected structure.
elements.clean_text: Offering further insight into the nature of this intricate architecture, pairs of oba1 and oba2 bridges link octanuclear zinc clusters to form a (4,4) 2-D sheet, and octanuclear zinc clusters are bridged by oba3 ligands to show a (3,6)-connected sheet. Two kinds of sheets extent to a (3,10)-connected layer by sharing octanuclear zinc clusters along the bc plane (see Figure S5 in the ). Furthermore, bbi ligands connect these (3,10)-connected layers along the a axis to form the ultimate (3,12)-connected structure.

elements.content: Previous example of (3,12)-connected framework is very rare. Up to date, only two supramolecular complexes have been observed by extensive hydrogen bonding. The (3,12)-connected 3D framework via using covalent linkage has not been observed in MOFs. O’Keeffe et al. have enumerated a (3,12)-connected net (ttt) based on a triangle as a 3-connected node and a truncated tetrahedron as a 12-connected node (see Figure S6 in the ). Each 3-connected node connects three 12-connected nodes, and each 12-connected node connects twelve 3-connected nodes. The 3-connected node and 12-connected nodes are in agreement with the ratio of 4:1. In this case, compound 1 is clearly different from the ttt network, where each 3-connected node connects three 12-connected nodes, and each 12-connected node connects six 3-connected nodes and six 12-connected nodes. The 3-connected node and 12-connected node show a ratio of 2:1. So the net in 1 defines a new topology for the (3,12)-connected coordination networks, which is not only unobserved but also unenumerated, and represents the highest connected binodal network topology for MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Previous example of (3,12)-connected framework is very rare. Up to date, only two supramolecular complexes have been observed by extensive hydrogen bonding. The (3,12)-connected 3D framework via using covalent linkage has not been observed in MOFs. O'Keeffe et al. have enumerated a (3,12)-connected net (ttt) based on a triangle as a 3-connected node and a truncated tetrahedron as a 12-connected node (see Figure S6 in the ). Each 3-connected node connects three 12-connected nodes, and each 12-connected node connects twelve 3-connected nodes. The 3-connected node and 12-connected nodes are in agreement with the ratio of 4:1. In this case, compound 1 is clearly different from the ttt network, where each 3-connected node connects three 12-connected nodes, and each 12-connected node connects six 3-connected nodes and six 12-connected nodes. The 3-connected node and 12-connected node show a ratio of 2:1. So the net in 1 defines a new topology for the (3,12)-connected coordination networks, which is not only unobserved but also unenumerated, and represents the highest connected binodal network topology for MOFs.

elements.content: Encouraged by the presence of nanosized octauclear zinc clusters in the framework, photovoltage (PV) transients were recorded for 1 at atmospheric pressure and room temperature (293 K). It is known that a PV signal arises upon the separation in space of light-induced excess-charge carriers, and that transient PV can be used for characterization of semiconductor materials. Figure S7 in the shows the PV transients for 1 at different intensities of the exciting laser pulse (355 nm). The transient PV signals of compound 1 display retardation in time, which is caused by slow and independent diffusion of excess electrons and holes. Although the intensities of the exciting laser pulses are different (0.05, 0.10, 0.20, and 0.30 mJ), the times at which their maxima arise are similar, appearing at about 3 × 10−7 s. Additionally, the PV transient signals are positive, which means that the photoexcited electrons move faster than holes toward the compound 1/indium tin oxide (ITO) interface. It is different from the similar heptanuclear and pentanuclear zinccarboxylate clusters, the signals of the PV transients show negative. The maxima of the transients are linearly enhanced when the intensity of the pulse is increased from 0.05 to 0.30 mJ. This observation implies that 1 possesses the characteristics of a diffusion PV transient, which is similar to the case for nanosized metal oxide semiconductors.
elements.clean_text: Encouraged by the presence of nanosized octauclear zinc clusters in the framework, photovoltage (PV) transients were recorded for 1 at atmospheric pressure and room temperature (293 K). It is known that a PV signal arises upon the separation in space of light-induced excess-charge carriers, and that transient PV can be used for characterization of semiconductor materials. Figure S7 in the  shows the PV transients for 1 at different intensities of the exciting laser pulse (355 nm). The transient PV signals of compound 1 display retardation in time, which is caused by slow and independent diffusion of excess electrons and holes. Although the intensities of the exciting laser pulses are different (0.05, 0.10, 0.20, and 0.30 mJ), the times at which their maxima arise are similar, appearing at about 3 × 10-7 s. Additionally, the PV transient signals are positive, which means that the photoexcited electrons move faster than holes toward the compound 1/indium tin oxide (ITO) interface. It is different from the similar heptanuclear and pentanuclear zinccarboxylate clusters, the signals of the PV transients show negative. The maxima of the transients are linearly enhanced when the intensity of the pulse is increased from 0.05 to 0.30 mJ. This observation implies that 1 possesses the characteristics of a diffusion PV transient, which is similar to the case for nanosized metal oxide semiconductors.

elements.content: In summary, we have prepared and characterized the first (3,12)-connected network via using covalent linkage based on nanosized octanuclear zinc clusters as 12-connected nodes and flexible carboxylate ligands as 3-connected nodes. It represents the highest-connected binodal network topology presently known for MOFs. Compound 1 not only provides an intriguing example of binodal high-connected frameworks but also exhibits interesting photoelectronic properties, which would facilitate the exploration of new types of semiconducting materials, especially among MOFs containing nanosized multinuclear metal clusters, in the near future.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have prepared and characterized the first (3,12)-connected network via using covalent linkage based on nanosized octanuclear zinc clusters as 12-connected nodes and flexible carboxylate ligands as 3-connected nodes. It represents the highest-connected binodal network topology presently known for MOFs. Compound 1 not only provides an intriguing example of binodal high-connected frameworks but also exhibits interesting photoelectronic properties, which would facilitate the exploration of new types of semiconducting materials, especially among MOFs containing nanosized multinuclear metal clusters, in the near future.

elements.content: Crystallographic data in CIF format; synthetic procedures, additional figures, TGA, PV, XRD, and luminescence spectra (PDF). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content: Crystal data for 1: monoclinic, space group P21/c, M r = 2354.50, a = 14.3100(17) Å, b = 29.265(3) Å, c = 11.0730(13) Å, β = 104.228(2)°, V = 4494.9(9) Å3, Z = 2, μ = 2.191 mm−1, D c = 1.740 Mg m−3, F(000) = 2380, T = 293(2) K, 21599 reflections collected, 7874 unique with R int = 0.0618, R 1 = 0.0604, wR 2 = 0.1142 (I > 2σ(I)), GOF = 1.063. Data collection was performed on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD diffractometer (Mo Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å)

metadata.title: A (3,12)-Connected 3D Metal-Organic Framework Based on Nanosized Octanuclear Zinc Clusters
